title: Part A
stimulusHtml: Select a point value to view scoring criteria, solutions, and/or examples and to score the response.
descriptions: The response does not identify the profit-maximizing quantity as 7 units and/or does not explain that the 7th unit is the last unit where the marginal revenue ($90) is greater than the marginal cost ($88); the firm will not produce the 8th unit because the marginal cost of producing it ($100) is greater than the marginal revenue earned ($90).

The response identifies the profit-maximizing quantity as 7 units and explains that the 7th unit is the last unit where the marginal revenue ($90) is greater than the marginal cost ($88); the firm will not produce the 8th unit because the marginal cost of producing it ($100) is greater than the marginal revenue earned ($90).

title: Part C
stimulusHtml: Select a point value to view scoring criteria, solutions, and/or examples and to score the response.
descriptions:
The response does not calculate the average fixed cost as $55 and/or does not show the work.

AFC= TFC Q = $275 5 =$55 MathType@MTEF@5@5@@4527@

title: Part D
stimulusHtml: Select a point value to view scoring criteria, solutions, and/or examples and to score the response.
descriptions: The response does not state that the number of firms in the industry will decrease and/or does not explain that negative economic profit will cause firms to exit the industry.
The response states that the number of firms in the industry will decrease and explains that negative economic profit will cause firms to exit the industry.

title: Part E
stimulusHtml: Select a point value to view scoring criteria, solutions, and/or examples and to score the response.
descriptions: The response does not state that the market price will increase and/or does not explain that with the exit of firms, the market supply will decrease, causing the price to increase.
The response states that the market price will increase and explains that with the exit of firms, the market supply will decrease, causing the price to increase.

title: Part F
stimulusHtml: Select a point value to view scoring criteria, solutions, and/or examples and to score the response.
descriptions: The response does not state that the demand for hats will decrease and/or does not explain that the negative cross-price elasticity of demand for hats with respect to the price of Good C means that the goods are complements; therefore, an increase in the price of Good C will lead to a decrease in the demand for hats.

The response states that that the demand for hats will decrease and explains that the negative cross-price elasticity of demand for hats with respect to the price of Good C means that the goods are complements; therefore, an increase in the price of Good C will lead to a decrease in the demand for hats.

title: Part G
stimulusHtml: Select a point value to view scoring criteria, solutions, and/or examples and to score the response.
descriptions:
The response does none of the following:

· States that the profit-maximizing quantity of Good C will decrease and explains that the decrease in market demand will decrease the market price (the firm’s marginal revenue), which will shift the marginal revenue curve downward at each quantity so that marginal cost will intersect marginal revenue at a lower quantity.

· States that the profit-maximizing quantity of Good C will decrease and explains that wages are a variable cost, so an increase in wages will shift the marginal cost curve upward at each quantity so that marginal cost will intersect marginal revenue at a lower quantity.

The response does one of the following:

· States that the profit-maximizing quantity of Good C will decrease and explains that the decrease in market demand will decrease the market price (the firm’s marginal revenue), which will shift the marginal revenue curve downward at each quantity so that marginal cost will intersect marginal revenue at a lower quantity.

· States that the profit-maximizing quantity of Good C will decrease and explains that wages are a variable cost, so an increase in wages will shift the marginal cost curve upward at each quantity so that marginal cost will intersect marginal revenue at a lower quantity.

The response does both of the following:

· States that the profit-maximizing quantity of Good C will decrease and explains that the decrease in market demand will decrease the market price (the firm’s marginal revenue), which will shift the marginal revenue curve downward at each quantity so that marginal cost will intersect marginal revenue at a lower quantity.

· States that the profit-maximizing quantity of Good C will decrease and explains that wages are a variable cost, so an increase in wages will shift the marginal cost curve upward at each quantity so that marginal cost will intersect marginal revenue at a lower quantity.
